bibl.title: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Henry Rose Carter, January 25, 1922

div1.p: LePrince writes that Carter's malaria abstracts and comments are valuable. He discusses Caldwell's yellow fever work in Mexico and upcoming malaria control work in southern Illinois, as well as other malaria work in the South.

div1.head: Letter from Joseph A. LePrince to Henry Rose Carter, January 25, 1922
div1.opener:
Mal. Abstract
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
Jan 25/22
Memphis Tenn.
Dear Dr Carter
div1.p:
I have just returned from
southern Illinois-

Regarding the abstracts - on anti
malaria work - the men in the field
have already spoken to me of them
and the consensus of opinion is
that the comment as now made is
often of more value than the abstract
itself- They now get the value of
the abstract where formerly it merely
kept them guessing as to what it
really meant- I think the abstract
with comment is worth very much
more to us all than the abstract without
comment-.

I have got one of the new young
I. H. B engineers Mr Rector interested in
catch basins (street corner storm water)
& he is going into it-

C2
B21

Of course we know its not anopheles
but if the public will not pay for malaria
control without culex nuisance removal
then its important- Also I am convinced
that under proper health officers the interest
of public in results of mosquito control can
be used in obtaining their interest in
control of soil pollution disease operations
where needed- It is so being done in Alabama.

I just had a letter from Dr Bert
Caldwell (formerly Bas Obispo) - now at Vera
Cruz & vicinity- He reports about 503
cases Y. F infor Mexico 1920 & 115 for 1921 - &
thinks he has the situation well in
hand at Vera Cruz - but more work
ahead I understood in smaller places -
probably to north or south of V. C.

The State H. D of Illinois expects to
take up malaria control in Southern
Illinois this year & is putting an engr
in the field- Carbondale will probably
do work & possibly Murpheesboro also
both on I. C. C-. I have been up there
& got back Sunday- There is considerable
malaria reported-

The quantity & prevalence of cat tail
growth near Carbondale, Herrin, etc
is astounding - & may be quite a problem.
Also the washing of slack from coal at
((2
(3)
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
coal mines silts up drainage
channels - the water pours over the
flat lands & cat tail growth is abun
dant in damp & wet areas so made

On Jan 19th at 7.05 P M at Carbondale
Illinois in the Roberts Hotel, say 100 yds from depot I was with
State San H. F. Engr H F Fergueson- We were having
our shoes shined in the coat room & he
slapped his cheek & said a mosquito bit
him- About a minute later it came back
& then another - we captured the second
& it was (Stegomyia)- A search in the
coat room showed adult Stegomyia both
male & female to be present- We captured
(4) four with a handkerchief as we catch
anopheles- Ive never been able to get
stegomyia before by swatting-

Next morning we got several more in
the same room- Beside Fergueson Mr
D B Ivenck Asst State San. Engr and Mr
Chandler, (State Biological Division?) were in
the cloak room 8 am Jan 20 & we caught some
more stegomyia- The hall boy & shoe shine
boys who sleep in this room said they were
bitten frequently every night- I started to run
C1
B28
((4
the breeding place down (locate it)
but changed my mind- As Mr Chandler
lives at Carbondale he can keep in touch
with the situation & see if they (Stegomyia)
are yet present in Feb March & up to June)
& if this is one of the ways they can & do
pass the winter in So. Illinois-

I am sending some of the captured
Stegomyia to Dr Howard, Wash D. C-.
Some of them have an absence of the
parallel lines - they look thus
in place of but one of those I
gave to Mr Chandler was a perfect specimen.

Of course I shall let you know of
the results-

I was interrupted & failed to explain re
the catch basins & Mr Rector- It appears
at Providence R. I they use a porous wall

A
B

The water goes into compart
ment B and slaps over into
other chamber over division
wall A which is porous -
after storm subsides all
remaining water in (B)
leaks through porous wall
A - & leaves dry weed in
chamber B-.

This is in print I am told
((5
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
& Im going to get Mr Rector to run
it down & we will have it checked -
& tried out it seems possible & not
expensive-.

Fisher has four new places
starting in S. C-

Dr Fricks will concentrate work
so far as practical in Alabama
& Mississippi this season.-
It is proper to do so-

He is trying to get the Ill. Central
to take hold-.
With best wishes
